image1.png.context: At the top of the manual, right after the title 'IPTVBOSS USER MANUAL' and before the overview text

image2.png.context: After download and docker links, before Cloud Provider Setup section. Links to PayPal donation

image3.png.context: Step 2: Click on Create an App
image3.png.description: Dropbox developer page showing 'Create an App' button

image4.png.context: Step 3: Choose: 1. Scoped Access, 2. App Folder, 3. Name your App
image4.png.description: Dropbox app creation dialog with options for Scoped Access, App Folder, and naming the app

image5.png.context: Step 4: Change the permissions of your Dropbox app, by clicking on the permissions tab & use the picture below to set your permission as required for IPTVBoss
image5.png.description: Dropbox app permissions tab showing required permissions for IPTVBoss

image6.png.context: Step 5: Open IPTVBoss and go to 'Settings' then 'IPTVBoss Settings'
image6.png.description: IPTVBoss settings dialog showing Dropbox cloud provider configuration with App Key and App Secret fields

image7.png.context: Step 1: Select the dropdown next to Google APIs and select New Project
image7.png.description: Google Cloud Console showing the project dropdown and 'New Project' option

image8.png.context: Step 2: Give your project a name and press create
image8.png.description: Google Cloud Console new project creation dialog with project name field

image9.png.context: Step 3: Make sure the project you created is selected in the dropdown next to 'Google APIs' at the top right. Then click '+ ENABLE APIS AND SERVICES'
image9.png.description: Google Cloud Console showing the '+ ENABLE APIS AND SERVICES' button

image10.png.context: Step 4: Search for 'drive' and then select 'Google Drive API'
image10.png.description: Google Cloud Console API library showing search results for 'drive' with Google Drive API

image11.png.context: Step 5: Click the blue 'Enable' button if it is not already enabled
image11.png.description: Google Drive API page showing the blue 'Enable' button

image12.png.context: Step 6: Select 'OAuth Consent Screen' on the left hand side
image12.png.description: Google Cloud Console showing the OAuth Consent Screen option in left sidebar

image13.png.description: OAuth consent screen type selection showing 'External' option

image14.png.context: Step 9: On the Scopes page, click 'Add or Remove Scopes'
image14.png.description: OAuth consent screen Scopes page with 'Add or Remove Scopes' button

image15.png.context: Step 10: Enable 'drive.appdate' and 'drive.file' and click 'update'. Click 'Save and Continue'
image15.png.description: Scopes selection dialog showing drive.appdate and drive.file scopes selected

image16.png.context: Step 13: If the App is left in 'Testing', tokens will expire after 7 days. To avoid this, click 'Publish App'. Then click confirm
image16.png.description: OAuth consent screen showing 'Publish App' button to avoid token expiration

image17.png.context: Step 14: Click 'Credentials' on the left hand side
image17.png.description: Google Cloud Console showing 'Credentials' option in left sidebar

image18.png.context: Step 15: Click 'Create Credentials' at the top and Select 'OAuth client ID'
image18.png.description: Credentials page showing 'Create Credentials' dropdown with 'OAuth client ID' option

image19.png.context: Step 16: In the Application type dropdown, select 'TVs and Limited Input devices'. Then click 'Create'
image19.png.description: OAuth client ID creation dialog showing application type dropdown with 'TVs and Limited Input devices' selected

image20.png.context: Step 17: Open IPTVBoss. Go to Settings, IPTVBoss Settings. Select 'Cloud Sync Enabled'. From the 'Cloud Provider' dropdown, select 'Google Drive'. Enter your Client Id and Client Secret. Press Authorize
image20.png.description: IPTVBoss settings dialog showing Google Drive cloud provider configuration with Client ID and Client Secret fields

image21.png.context: To activate your IPTVBoss Pro subscription, simply enter your IPTVBoss token (which you will receive in your welcome email from IPTVBoss) in the IPTVBoss Pro Setting dialog under the Settings menu in IPTVBoss
image21.png.description: Menu showing how to access IPTVBoss Pro Settings dialog

image22.png.context: After image21, showing the actual IPTVBoss Pro subscription token entry
image22.png.description: IPTVBoss Pro Settings dialog with token entry field

image23.png.context: The layout manager panel is the main setup page of IPTVBoss. Here you will create and edit layouts that allow you to take your provider sources and epgs and customize them as you desire
image23.png.description: Layout Manager panel showing layout list and configuration options

image24.png.context: The Sources Manager panel is where you will manage all your iptv sources you want to edit and epg sources you want to use. The Sources Manager can be found under the 'Sources Menu'
image24.png.description: Sources Manager panel showing playlist sources and EPG sources management interface

image25.png.context: Add EPG - Name the EPG Source. To use the IPTVBoss built-in guides, click the dropdown window in 'Source' and choose the EPG you want to add. You can also add your own EPG by pasting the URL
image25.png.description: Add EPG dialog showing EPG source dropdown with built-in guide options

image26.png.context: An example of a custom EPG setting I use is pictured below. Shows drag/drop components from the bottom into the Title & Description windows
image26.png.description: EPG Layout Settings dialog showing custom title and description configuration with draggable components

image27.png.context: These are examples of the results using the above settings. First example image
image27.png.description: Example result of custom EPG layout showing formatted program title and description in player

image28.png.context: These are examples of the results using the above settings. Second example image
image28.png.description: Another example result of custom EPG layout showing formatted program information

image29.png.context: These are examples of the results using the above settings. Third example image
image29.png.description: Third example result of custom EPG layout showing formatted program details

image30.png.section: Importing Channels - Import Channels From Sources Dialog
image30.png.context: In this GUI, you import channels from your sources into your layout. You can import by 'Source', which imports all enabled groups from the selected Sources; you can import by Category; or you can import by Channel
image30.png.description: Import Channels From Sources dialog showing source selection, categories list, and channels list with import options

image31.png.section: Importing Channels - Import Channels From Layouts Dialog
image31.png.context: In this GUI, you import channels from your existing layouts into another layout. You can import by 'Layout', which imports all enabled groups from the selected Layouts; you can import by Group; or you can import by Channel
image31.png.description: Import Channels From Layouts dialog showing layout selection, groups list, and channels list with import options

image32.png.context: Most function/actions that are completed on this panel can be undone or redone using the 'Undo' and 'Redo' functions on the top toolbar
image32.png.description: Layout Editor panel showing groups list, channels list, channel options, and group options interface

image33.png.context: Example: I want to map US Network channels using IPTVBoss built-in guides. I prefer to see the channels with no mapping, so I check the 'Highlight Missing EPGs' box in the 'Preferences' options at the top. Also, I highlight all channels I plan to 'Auto' map
image33.png.description: Channel list showing highlighted channels with missing EPG mappings ready for auto-mapping

image34.png.context: Then I would click on 'Search Options' buttons and uncheck the guides that I don't want interfering. In this case, UK/Can
image34.png.description: Search Options dialog showing checkboxes for different EPG guides (US, UK, Can) to enable/disable for mapping

image35.png.context: Finally, click 'Auto' in the EPG Assignment section of the Channel Editor. Any channel that doesn't 'Auto', try using 'Manual' and it more than likely will be the first option
image35.png.description: Channel Editor showing EPG Assignment section with Auto and Manual buttons and EPG sensitivity settings

image36.png.context: The New Channel Manager can be used to determine how new channels from enabled categories will be treated when added by your provider. You are free to manage how channels are added, and from what categories into what Layout Groups
image36.png.description: New Channel Manager dialog showing Layout Groups on left and Included Categories with drag-and-drop interface

image37.png.context: Once in the 'Manage User' dialog, you can add multiple users, changing the credentials for each user as necessary. Each playlist can be independently enabled/disabled per User. Users can also be enabled/disabled
image37.png.description: Manage Users dialog showing user list with username/password fields and playlist enable/disable options

image38.png.context: You can also enable users for a layout from the Layout Manager Screen by clicking on the Manage Users button of a selected Layout. Right clicking a user will toggle them between Enabled and Disabled
image38.png.description: Layout Users dialog showing list of users that can be enabled/disabled for a specific layout

image39.png.context: Before starting the XC Server, it is important to set the XC API Settings in IPTVBoss. To do this, go to 'Settings', 'XC Server Settings'
image39.png.description: XC Server Settings dialog showing server configuration options including URL, port, sync times, and XC enable options

image40.png.section: IPTVBoss XC Server - Running the XC Server
image40.png.context: If you are running the server on a headless system (or as a service). The log and commands can be accessed through a url endpoint. Accessing the endpoint will give a page that looks like the following. It will contain the server log as well as links for Stopping and Reloading the server
image40.png.description: XC Server web interface showing server log and control buttons (Stop/Reload) for headless operation

image41.png.context: User links for XC can be found under the layouts pane in IPTVBoss. Simply look for the 'View XC Login' button. Once looking at the user links, links can be copied to clipboard by simply clicking the user
image41.png.description: XC User Links dialog showing list of users with their XC API login credentials and URLs

image42.png.section: Setting up IPTVBoss XC Server as a Service - Windows
image42.png.context: Setting up as a service in windows is more complicated than Linux. For windows users, I suggest just using the task scheduler to start the server on startup
image42.png.description: Windows Task Scheduler showing basic settings for creating a task to auto-start IPTVBoss XC Server

image43.png.section: Setting up IPTVBoss XC Server as a Service - Windows
image43.png.context: After basic task settings. Program/Script: C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe. Add arguments: /C iptvboss-c -xcserver
image43.png.description: Windows Task Scheduler Actions tab showing program/script and arguments configuration for starting XC Server
